children.name: body
children.text: RESTAPIRequestBody
children.text2:
The body of the request. You can access data from the body object using the
                RESTAPIRequestBody API.

children.name: Example
children.text: var requestBody = request.body // Returns instance of RESTAPIRequestBody

children.name: body
children.text: The body of the request.

children.name: Example
children.text: var headers = request.headers; var acceptHeader = headers.Accept; var myCustomHeader = headers.myCustom; var specialHeader = headers['special - header'];

children.name: headers
children.text: object
children.text2: All headers from the request, and their values.

children.name: headers
children.text: All headers from the request.

children.name: Example
children.text: var pathParams = request.pathParams; var tableName = pathParams.tableName; //‘myApp_table’ var id = pathParams.id; //‘1234’
children.text2: In this , the scripted REST API endpoint follows this format: https://instance.service-now.com/api/now/myservice/{tableName}/{id}. The request being processed uses this URL: https://instance.service-now.com/api/now/myservice/myApp_table/1234.

children.name: pathParams
children.text: Object
children.text2:
The path parameters as a script object. Available path parameters depend on the
                web service configuration.

children.name: pathParams
children.text: The path parameters passed in the request URI.

children.name: Example
children.text: var queryParams = request.queryParams; var isActiveQuery = queryParams.active; // [false] var nameQueryVal = queryParams.name; // ['now']
children.text2: In this , the request being processed uses this URL: https://<instance_rest_endpoint>?active=false&name=now. Note the active and name parameters.

children.name: queryParams
children.text: Array
children.text2: The query parameters from the web service request.

children.name: queryParams
children.text: The query parameters from the web service request.

children.name: Example
children.text: var query = request.queryString; //"active=false&name=now"
children.text2: In this , the request being processed uses this URL: https://<instance_rest_endpoint>?active=false&name=now. Note the query active=false&name=now.

children.name: queryString
children.text: String
children.text2: The entire query for the request.

children.name: queryString
children.text: The entire query added to the endpoint URI.

children.name: Example
children.text: var query = request.uri; //"api/now/table/myTable"
children.text2: In this , the request being processed uses this URL: https://instance.service-now.com/api/now/table/myTable?active=false&name=now.

children.name: uri
children.text: String
children.text2: The request URI, excluding domain information.

children.name: uri
children.text: The request URI, excluding domain information.

children.name: Example
children.text: var query = request.url; //"https://instance.service-now.com/api/now/table/myTable?active=false&name=now"
children.text2: In this , the request being processed uses this URL: https://instance.service-now.com/api/now/table/myTable?active=false&name=now.

children.name: url
children.text: String
children.text2: The entire request URL.

children.name: url
children.text: The entire request URL.

children.name: String
children.text: The value of the specified header.

children.name: header
children.text: String
children.text2: The name of the header, such as accept or content-type.

children.name: Example
children.text: var acceptHeader = request.getHeader('accept');

children.name: getHeader(String header)
children.text: Returns the value of a specific header from the web service request.

children.name: Array
children.text:
An array of string values where each string is a content type, such as
                application/json.

children.name: getSupportedResponseContentTypes()
children.text: Get the content types specified in the request Accept header.

name: RESTAPIRequest - Scoped, Global
text:
A RESTAPIRequest object allows you to access scripted REST API request details in
  scripts.
text2: Note: You cannot instantiate objects of this type. Objects of this type are created automatically and are accessible only in scripted REST API resource scripts.

children.name: Example
children.text: var entry; var id; var requestBody = request.body; var requestData = requestBody.data; //May be an array or a single object if (requestData instanceof Array) { entry = requestData[0].name; // 'user1' id = requestData[0].id; // '1234' } else { entry = requestData.name; // 'user1' id = requestData.id; // '1234' }

children.name: data
children.text: Object or Array
children.text2:
The request content. This can be a single object or an array of objects
                depending on the request.

children.name: data
children.text: The content of the request body.
children.text2: Note: REST web services consume data, datastream, and dataString via stream. Because streams are only consumed once, only one can be called. For example, if calling both data and dataString, the second call will return empty.

children.name: Example
children.text: var requestBody = request.body; var requestStream = requestBody.dataStream;

children.name: dataStream
children.text: Object
children.text2:
The content of the request body. You can pass the stream to a separate API,
                such as to create an attachment from the request or forward the request to a
                different endpoint.

children.name: dataStream
children.text: The content of the request body, as a stream.
children.text2: Note: REST web services consume data, datastream, and dataString via stream. Because streams are only consumed once, only one can be called. For example, if calling both data and dataString, the second call will return empty.

children.name: Example
children.text: var requestBody = request.body; var requestString = requestBody.dataString;

children.name: dataString
children.text: String
children.text2: The content of the request body.

children.name: dataString
children.text: The content of the request body, as a String.
children.text2: Note: REST web services consume data, datastream, and dataString via stream. Because streams are only consumed once, only one can be called. For example, if calling both data and dataString, the second call will return empty.

children.name: Example
children.text: var requestBody = request.body; requestBody.hasNext(); // returns true if the request contains a single entry or multiple entries requestBody. nextEntry(); // returns next available entry //calling second time requestBody.hasNext(); // returns false if the request contains a single entry, or true if the request contains multiple entries

children.name: boolean
children.text:
Flag indicating whether there are additional entries in the request body.
Possible values:
  • true: Additional entries are available. As nextEntry() is called, hasNext() continues to be true until the last matching record is loaded.
  • false: No additional entries.

children.name: hasNext()
children.text: Determines if there are additional entries in the request body.
children.text2: Use this method with the nextEntry() method to iterate over multiple request body entries.

children.name: Example
children.text: var requestBody = request.body; var requestEntry = requestBody.nextEntry(); // returns available entry if there is only one entry, or the first entry if there are multiple. var name = requestEntry.name; // ‘user1’ // Calling second time requestEntry = requestBody.nextEntry(); // returns undefined if there is only one entry, or the second entry if there are multiple.

children.name: Object
children.text: A single entry from the request body.

children.name: Example
children.text: var requestBody = request.body; while(requestBody.hasNext()){ var entry = requestBody.nextEntry(); }
children.text2: This  demonstrates using hasNext() with nextEntry().

children.name: nextEntry()
children.text: Retrieve one entry from the request body as a script object.
children.text2: Use this method with the hasNext() method to iterate over multiple request body entries.

name: RESTAPIRequestBody - Scoped, Global
text:
A RESTAPIRequestBody object allows you to access the body content of a scripted REST
  API request in scripts.

children.name: RESTAPIResponseStream - Scoped, Global
children.text:
The ResponseStreamWriter for this response. You can use this object to write
                directly to the response stream.

children.name: Example
children.text: response.setContentType('application/json'); response.setStatus(200); var writer = response.getStreamWriter();

children.name: getStreamWriter()
children.text:
Returns the ResponseStreamWriter for this response, allowing you to write directly to
    the response stream.
children.text2: Set the content type and status code using the setHeaders and setStatus functions prior to calling the getStreamWriter function.

children.name: body
children.text: Object
children.text2:
The response body, as a JavaScript object.

The body content is automatically serialized to JSON or XML depending on the value of the Accept header passed in the request.

children.name: Example
children.text: var body = {}; body.name = "incident"; body.number = "1234"; body.caller = {"id": "user1"}; response.setBody(body);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: Example
children.text: var bodyArray = []; var body = {}; body.name = "incident"; body.number = "1234"; body.caller = {"id":"user1"}; bodyArray.push(body); response.setBody(bodyArray);

children.name: setBody(Object body)
children.text: Sets the body content to send in the web service response.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: contentType
children.text: String
children.text2: The content type of the response body, such as application/json.

children.name: Example
children.text: response.setContentType('application/json');

children.name: setContentType(String contentType)
children.text: Assigns a value to the Content-Type header in the web service response.
children.text2:
You must set a response content type before writing the response. The content type is set automatically for string responses, based on the request Accept header value.

Setting an invalid content type causes the response to default to JSON. Failing to set a content type results in a status code 500 error when sending a binary response.

See the W3 Content-Type header documentation for more information about this header.

children.name: error
children.text: Object
children.text2: Error object.

children.name: Example
children.text: var queryParams = request.queryParams; var userId = String(queryParams.user_id || ''); var fileId = String(queryParams.file_id || ''); if (!userId || !fileId){ response.setError(new sn_ws_err.BadRequestError('Missing required parameters.')); return; }
children.text2:
The following  shows how to return an error from within a scripted REST
        resource.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setError(Object error)
children.text: Configures the REST response to return an error.

children.name: Example
children.text: response.setHeader("Location","<URI>");

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: header
children.text: String
children.text2: The header you want to set.

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2: The value to assign the specified header.

children.name: setHeader(String header, String value)
children.text: Assign a value to a REST service response header.

children.name: Example
children.text: var headers = {}; headers.X-Total-Count=100; headers.Location=‘https://instance.service-now.com/<endpoint_to_resource>'; response.setHeaders(headers);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: headers
children.text: Object
children.text2:
A JavaScript object listing each header and the value to assign that
                header.

children.name: setHeaders(Object headers)
children.text: Sets the headers for the web service response.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setLocation(String location)
children.text: Assigns a value to the Location header in the web service response.
children.text2: See the W3 Location header documentation for more information about this header.

children.name: status
children.text: Number
children.text2:
The status code to send in the response, such as 200 to indicate success.
                Passing a non-numerical value, such as a string, causes the status code to default
                to 0.

children.name: Example
children.text: response.setStatus(200);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setStatus(Number status)
children.text: Sets the status code number for the web service response.

name: RESTAPIResponse - Scoped, Global
text:
A RESTAPIResponse object allows you to build a RESTful response to a scripted REST API
  request.
text2: Note: You cannot instantiate objects of this type. Objects of this type are created automatically and are accessible only in scripted REST API resource scripts.

children.name: Example
children.text: (function process(/*RESTAPIRequest*/ request, /*RESTAPIResponse*/ response) { response.setContentType('application/json'); response.setStatus(200); var gsa = new GlideSysAttachment(); var attachmentStream = new gsa.getContentStream(<sys_id of attachment>); var writer = response.getStreamWriter(); writer.writeStream(attachmentStream); })(request, response);
children.text2: The following  is for scoped applications:

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: stream
children.text: Object
children.text2: An attachment or a response stream from a third-party service.

children.name: Example
children.text: (function process(/*RESTAPIRequest*/ request, /*RESTAPIResponse*/ response) { response.setContentType('application/json'); response.setStatus(200); var attachmentStream = new GlideSysAttachmentInputStream(<sys_id of attachment>); var writer = response.getStreamWriter(); writer.writeStream(attachmentStream); })(request, response);
children.text2: The following  is for global applications:

children.name: writeStream(Object stream)
children.text: Write an input stream to the response stream.
children.text2:
You must set the content type and status code before calling the writeStream() method or the response will fail. You cannot modify these values after calling the writeStream() method.

Note:

It is the responsibility of the script author to obtain the stream from a third-party service.

children.name: data
children.text: String
children.text2: The string to add to the response data.

children.name: Example
children.text: response.setContentType('application/json'); response.setStatus(200); var writer = response.getStreamWriter(); var body ={ name:user1, id: 1234, roles: [ { name: admin }, { name: itil } ] } writer.writeString("{'name':'user','id':'1234'}"); writer.writeString(JSON.stringify(body));

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: writeString(String data)
children.text: Write string data to the response stream.
children.text2: You must set the content type and status code before calling the writeString() method or the response will fail. You cannot modify these values after calling the writeString() method.

name: RESTAPIResponseStream - Scoped, Global
text:
A RESTAPIResponseStream object allows you to write directly to the scripted REST API
  response stream.
text2:
Use RESTAPIResponseStream methods to build web service APIs in the Scripted REST API feature.
Note: You cannot instantiate objects of this type. Objects of this type are created automatically and are accessible only in scripted REST API resource scripts.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2();

children.name: RESTMessageV2()
children.text: Instantiates an empty RESTMessageV2 object.
children.text2: When using an object instantiated this way, you must manually specify an HTTP method and endpoint.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: The name of the REST message record.

children.name: methodName
children.text: String
children.text2:
The name of the HTTP method to use, such as GET/get or PUT/put - case
                insensitive.

children.name: RESTMessageV2(String name, String methodName)
children.text:
Instantiates a RESTMessageV2 object using information from a REST message
    record.
children.text2:
You must have a REST message record defined before you can use this constructor.

In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); //Might throw exception if http connection timed out or some issue with sending request itself because of encryption/decryption of password.

children.name: RESTResponse
children.text: The response returned by the REST provider.

children.name: execute()
children.text: Sends the REST message to the endpoint.
children.text2: In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.executeAsync(); //Might throw exception if http connection timed out or some issue with sending request itself because of encryption/decryption of password.

children.name: RESTResponse
children.text: The response returned by the REST provider.

children.name: executeAsync()
children.text:
Sends the REST message to the endpoint asynchronously. The instance does not wait for a
    response from the web service provider when making asynchronous calls.
children.text2: In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance. When using executeAsync, consider processing the response body in a separate business rule to take advantage of the asynchronous call.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var endpoint = sm.getEndpoint();

children.name: String
children.text: The URL of the REST web service provider.

children.name: getEndpoint()
children.text: Gets the URL of the endpoint for the REST message.
children.text2: In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var body = sm.getRequestBody();

children.name: String
children.text: the REST message body.

children.name: getRequestBody()
children.text: Gets the content of the REST message body.
children.text2: In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var header = sm.getRequestHeader("Accept");

children.name: String
children.text: The value of the specified header.

children.name: headerName
children.text: String
children.text2: Request header you want to get the value for.

children.name: getRequestHeader(String headerName)
children.text: Gets the value for an HTTP header specified in the REST message.
children.text2:
By default, this method cannot return the value for a header set automatically by the system. To grant this method access to all headers, set the property glide.http.log_debug to true.

In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var headers = sm.getRequestHeaders();

children.name: Object
children.text: An Object that maps the name of each header to the associated value.

children.name: getRequestHeaders()
children.text:
Gets HTTP headers that were set by the REST client and the associated
    values.
children.text2:
This method does not return headers set automatically by the system. To configure this method to return all headers, set the property glide.http.log_debug to true.

In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: tableName
children.text: String
children.text2:
Specify the table that contains the record you want to attach the saved file
                to.

children.name: Example
children.text: (function sampleRESTMessageV2() { try{ var request = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2(); request.setHttpMethod('get'); var attachment_sys_id = '<attachment_record_sys_id>', tablename = 'incident', recordSysId = '<incident_sys_id>', response, httpResponseStatus, filename ='<filename>'; //endpoint - ServiceNow REST Attachment API request.setEndpoint('https://<instance_name>.service-now.com/api/now/attachment/' + attachment_sys_id +'/file'); request.setBasicAuth('<username>', '<password>'); //RESTMessageV2 - saveResponseBodyAsAttachment(String tableName, String recordSysId, String fileName) request.saveResponseBodyAsAttachment(tablename, recordSysId, filename); response = request.execute(); httpResponseStatus = response.getStatusCode(); gs.info(" http response status_code: " + httpResponseStatus); } catch(ex){ var message = ex.getMessage(); gs.info(message); } })();

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: recordSysId
children.text: String
children.text2: Specify the sys_id of the record you want to attach the saved file to.

children.name: fileName
children.text: String
children.text2: Specify the file name to give to the saved file.

children.name: saveResponseBodyAsAttachment(String tableName, String recordSysId, String fileName)
children.text:
Configures the REST message to save the returned response body as an attachment
    record.
children.text2:
When you use this function with a REST message that is sent through a MID server, the MID server user must have any roles required to read and write attachment records, as well as any roles required to read and write records on the table specified in the tableName parameter.

The response body does not need to be a binary file to be saved as an attachment. Response bodies using text formats, such as JSON or XML can also be saved. If the instance fails to save the attachment, call getErrorMessage() on the related RESTResponseV2 object for error details.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: tableName
children.text: String
children.text2:
Specify the table that contains the record you want to attach the saved file
                to.

children.name: recordSysId
children.text: String
children.text2: Specify the sys_id of the record you want to attach the saved file to.

children.name: fileName
children.text: String
children.text2: Specify the file name to give to the saved file.

children.name: encryptContext
children.text: String
children.text2:
Specify the sys_id of an encryption context. The saved file is encrypted using
                this context.

children.name: saveResponseBodyAsAttachment(String tableName, String recordSysId, String fileName, String encryptContext)
children.text:
Configures the REST message to save the returned response body as an encrypted
    attachment record.
children.text2:
When you use this function with a REST message that is sent through a MID server, the MID server user must have any roles required to read and write attachment records, as well as any roles required to read and write records on the table specified in the tableName parameter.

The response body does not need to be a binary file to be saved as an attachment. Response bodies using text formats, such as JSON or XML can also be saved. If the instance fails to save the attachment, call getErrorMessage() on the related RESTResponseV2 object for error details.

children.name: Example
children.text: var requestBody; var responseBody; var status; var sm; try{ // Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>", "get"); //set auth profile to an OAuth 2.0 profile record. sm.setAuthenticationProfile('oauth2', '1234adsf123212131123qasdsf'); sm.setStringParameter("symbol", "NOW"); sm.setStringParameterNoEscape("xml_data","<data>test</data>"); //In milliseconds. Wait at most 10 seconds for response from http request. sm.setHttpTimeout(10000); //Might throw exception if http connection timed out or some issue //with sending request itself because of encryption/decryption of password. response = sm.execute(); responseBody = response.haveError() ? response.getErrorMessage() : response.getBody(); status = response.getStatusCode(); } catch(ex) { responseBody = ex.getMessage(); status = '500'; } finally { requestBody = sm ? sm.getRequestBody():null; }

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: type
children.text: String
children.text2:
The type of authentication profile to use. Valid values are 'basic' to use
                basic authentication, or 'oauth2' to use OAuth 2.0.

children.name: profileId
children.text: String
children.text2:
The sys_id of an authentication profile record. When using basic auth, specify
                the sys_id of a Basic Auth Configuration [sys_auth_profile_basic] record. When using
                OAuth 2.0, specify the sys_id of a OAuth Entity Profile [oauth_entity_profile]
                record.

children.name: setAuthenticationProfile(String type, String profileId)
children.text:
Sets the credentials for the REST message using an existing basic auth or OAuth 2.0
    profile.
children.text2: In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setBasicAuth("username","password");

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: userName
children.text: String
children.text2: Username you want to use to authenticate the REST message.

children.name: userPass
children.text: String
children.text2: Password for the specified user.

children.name: setBasicAuth(String userName, String userPass)
children.text: Sets basic authentication headers for the REST message.
children.text2:
Setting security values using this method overrides basic authentication values defined for the REST message record.

In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: correlator
children.text: String
children.text2: Unique identifier

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setEccCorrelator("unique_identifier");

children.name: setEccCorrelator(String correlator)
children.text: Associates outbound requests and the resulting response record in the ECC queue. This method only applies to REST messages sent through a MID Server.
children.text2:
The correlator provided populates the Agent correlator field on the ECC queue record for the response. Provide a unique correlator for each outbound request to associate the correct results in the ECC queue with the request when designing asynchronous automation through a MID Server.

In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: The name of the parameter, such as source.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setEccParameter("source","http://very.long.endpoint.url");

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2: The value to assign to the specified parameter.

children.name: setEccParameter(String name, String value)
children.text:
Overrides a value from the database by writing to the REST message payload. This method
    only applies to REST messages sent through a MID Server.
children.text2:
Use this method when a value from the REST message in the database is invalid, such as when the endpoint URL is longer than the maximum REST endpoint field length. You can set only the endpoint URL using this method by passing source as the name parameter.

In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: endpoint
children.text: String
children.text2: The URL of the REST provider you want to interface with.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2(); sm.setEndpoint("http://web.service.endpoint");

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setEndpoint(String endpoint)
children.text: Sets the endpoint for the REST message.
children.text2: By default, the REST message uses the endpoint specified in the REST message record. Use this method to override this default. You must call this method when using the RESTMessageV2 - RESTMessageV2() constructor with no parameters.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2(); sm.setHttpMethod("post");

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: method
children.text: String
children.text2: HTTP method to perform.

children.name: setHttpMethod(String method)
children.text: Sets the HTTP method this REST message performs, such as GET or PUT.
children.text2: You must set an HTTP method when using the RESTMessageV2 - RESTMessageV2() constructor with no parameters.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setHttpTimeout(6000);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: timeoutMs
children.text: Number
children.text2:
Amount of time, in milliseconds, before the call to the REST provider times
                out.

children.name: setHttpTimeout(Number timeoutMs)
children.text:
Sets the amount of time the REST message waits for a response from the web service
    provider before the request times out.
children.text2: In the following example, replace REST_message_record with the name of the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: Example
children.text: var rm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2(); rm.setLogLevel(‘all’);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: level
children.text: String
children.text2: The log level. Valid values are basic, elevated, and all.

children.name: setLogLevel(String level)
children.text: Sets the log level for this message and the corresponding response.
children.text2: Setting a log level using the RESTMessageV2 API overrides the log level configured on the REST message record. This log level may not apply if the endpoint domain is excluded, or if the property glide.outbound_http_log.override is true. To view outbound web service logs, navigate to System Logs > Outbound HTTP Requests.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: midServer
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the MID Server to use. Your instance must have an active MID Server with the specified name.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setMIDServer("mid_server_name");
children.text2:
In the following , replace <var class="keyword varname">REST_message_record</var> with the name of
        the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: setMIDServer(String midServer)
children.text: Configures the REST message to communicate through a MID Server.

children.name: profileName
children.text: String
children.text2: The Name of the protocol profile to use for mutual authentication.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setMutualAuth("mutual_auth_profile_name");
children.text2:
In the following , replace <var class="keyword varname">REST_message_record</var> with the name of
        the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setMutualAuth(String profileName)
children.text: Sets the mutual authentication protocol profile for the REST message.
children.text2: Setting a protocol profile using this method overrides the protocol profile selected for the REST message record.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the URL parameter to pass.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2(); //Set up message, including endpoint and authentication sm.setQueryParameter("sysparm_query","active=true^ORDERBYnumber^ORDERBYDESCcategory");

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2: Value to assign the URL parameter.

children.name: setQueryParameter(String name, String value)
children.text: Appends a parameter to the end of the request URL with the form name=value.
children.text2: For example, the code setQueryParameter("sysparm_query","active=true^ORDERBYnumber^ORDERBYDESCcategory"); appends the text sysparm_query=active=true^ORDERBYnumber^ORDERBYDESCcategory to the request URL.

children.name: body
children.text: String
children.text2: Request body to send.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("Update user","post"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var body = "<Message body content>"; sm.setRequestBody(body);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setRequestBody(String body)
children.text:
Sets the body content to send to the web service provider when using PUT or POST HTTP
    methods.
children.text2: When you set the body content using this method, variables in the body are not substituted for parameters from the REST message function record. You must explicitly define all values within the REST message body.

children.name: attachmentSysId
children.text: String
children.text2:
Sys_id of the Attachment [sys_attachment] record you want to send in this REST
                message.

children.name: Example
children.text: (function sampleRESTMessageV2() { try { var request = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2(); request.setHttpMethod('post'); request.setEndpoint('<web service endpoint URL>'); request.setRequestBodyFromAttachment('<attachment sys_id>'); var response = request.execute(); var httpResponseStatus = response.getStatusCode(); gs.info("http response status_code: " + httpResponseStatus); } catch (ex) { var message = ex.getMessage(); gs.info(message); } })();

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setRequestBodyFromAttachment(String attachmentSysId)
children.text: Sets the request body using an existing attachment record.
children.text2: When you use this function with a REST message that is sent through a MID Server, the MID Server user must have any roles required to read attachment records.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setRequestHeader("Accept","Application/json");
children.text2:
In the following , replace <var class="keyword varname">REST_message_record</var> with the name of
        the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the header.

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2: Value to assign to the specified header.

children.name: setRequestHeader(String name, String value)
children.text: Sets an HTTP header in the REST message to the specified value.

children.name: requestorContext
children.text: String

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: requestorId
children.text: String

children.name: setRequestorProfile(String requestorContext, String requestorId)
children.text:
Overrides the default requestor profile for the REST message in order to retrieve an
    OAuth access token associated with a different requestor.
children.text2: This method applies only to REST messages configured to use OAuth 2.0 authentication. This method is optional and is unnecessary in most configurations.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2:
Name of the REST message variable. This parameter must be defined in the REST
                message record before you can assign a value to it.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setStringParameter("s","NOW");
children.text2:
In the following , replace <var class="keyword varname">REST_message_record</var> with the name of
        the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2: Value to assign the variable.

children.name: setStringParameter(String name, String value)
children.text:
Sets a REST message function variable with the specified name from the REST message
    record to the specified value.
children.text2: XML reserved characters in the value are converted to the equivalent escaped characters. Use setStringParameterNoEscape to set a variable without escaping XML reserved characters.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2:
Name of the REST message variable. This parameter must be defined in the REST
                message record before you can assign a value to it.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("<REST_message_record>","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setStringParameterNoEscape("s","NOW");
children.text2:
In the following , replace <var class="keyword varname">REST_message_record</var> with the name of
        the REST message record from your instance.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2: Value to assign the variable.

children.name: setStringParameterNoEscape(String name, String value)
children.text:
Sets a REST message function variable with the specified name from the REST message
    record to the specified value.
children.text2: This method is equivalent to setStringParameter but does not escape XML reserved characters.

name: RESTMessageV2 - Scoped, Global
text:
The RESTMessageV2 API allows you to send
  outbound REST messages
  using JavaScript.
text2:
Use the RESTResponseV2 API to manage the response returned by the REST provider.

You can use this API in scoped applications, or within the global scope.

children.name: List<GlideHTTPHeader>
children.text:
List of headers contained in the response. Each header is represented as a
                GlideHTTPHeader object which contains the header <var class="keyword varname">name</var> and
                  <var class="keyword varname">value</var>.

children.name: Output
children.text:
X-Is-Logged-In: true
X-Transaction-ID: e3003cb2db8c
X-Total-Count: 66
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
Pragma: no-store,no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache,no-store,must-revalidate,max-age=-1
Expires: 0
Content-Type: application/json;charset=UTF-8
Date: Fri, 14 May 2021 16:05:10 GMT
Connection: close
Server: ServiceNow
JSESSIONID=5041870726ADADFAB2EE2BF8E7E01596; Path=/; HttpOnly; SameSite=None; Secure
Set-Cookie: glide_user=; Max-Age=0; Expires=Thu, 01-Jan-1970 00:00:10 GMT; Path=/; HttpOnly; SameSite=None; Secure
Set-Cookie: glide_user_session=; Max-Age=0; Expires=Thu, 01-Jan-1970 00:00:10 GMT; Path=/; HttpOnly; SameSite=None; Secure
Set-Cookie: glide_user_route=glide.f1aa2015b3fa5fa8dfe567386cde8fd5; Max-Age=2147483647; Expires=Wed, 01-Jun-2089 19:19:17 GMT; Path=/; HttpOnly; SameSite=None; Secure
Set-Cookie: glide_session_store=AF003CB2DB8CF8103DD9C39D139619C7; Max-Age=1800; Expires=Fri, 14-May-2021 16:35:10 GMT; Path=/; HttpOnly; SameSite=None; Secure
Set-Cookie: BIGipServerpool_ddershem=2643023626.45630.0000; path=/; Httponly; Secure; SameSite=None; Secure
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=63072000; includeSubDomains
children.text2: headers

children.name: Example
children.text: var request = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2(); request.setEndpoint('http://<SN_Instance_host>/api/now/table/incident'); request.setHttpMethod('GET'); request.setBasicAuth('username', 'password'); request.setRequestHeader("Accept", "application/json"); var res = request.execute(); if (res.getStatusCode() != 200) { gs.info('Bad Request'); } var headers = res.getAllHeaders(); for(var i in headers){ gs.info(headers[i].name + ': ' + headers[i].value); }
children.text2:
The follow code  shows how to call the REST Table API and then lists out all of the
        headers found in the response.

children.name: getAllHeaders()
children.text:
Returns all headers contained in the response, including any duplicate
    headers.

children.name: String
children.text: REST response body.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("Yahoo Finance","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); var responseBody = response.getBody();

children.name: getBody()
children.text: Gets the content of the REST response body.
children.text2: Use this function when you want to get the request body as text content. Do not use this method when saving the response as a binary attachment. If a RESTMessageV2 object called the saveResponseBodyAsAttachment(...) function, using getBody() on the associated RESTResponseV2 object will cause an error. When saving the response as an attachment, if the outbound REST message fails, call getErrorMessage() on the response to retrieve the body content.

children.name: Object
children.text:
Array of strings representing cookies. Iterate through the array to perform
                operations on each cookie.

children.name: Output
children.text:
cookie: JSESSIONID=4135AA97A5D12DA22EF614AA2B0CAFD8.node20; Path=/; Secure; HttpOnly
cookie: SABASESSIONID=370152970.36895.0000; path=/

children.name: Example
children.text: var cookies = response.getCookies(); for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; i++) { gs.info('cookie: ' + cookies.get(i)); }
children.text2: Display individual cookies from the response.

children.name: getCookies()
children.text: Returns all cookies included in the response.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("Yahoo Finance","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); var errorCode = response.getErrorCode();

children.name: Number
children.text: Numeric error code, such as 1 for socket timeout.

children.name: getErrorCode()
children.text: Gets the numeric error code if there was an error during the REST transaction.
children.text2:
This error code is specific to the Now Platform, it is not an HTTP error code. Provide this error code if you require assistance from ServiceNow Customer Support.

Note: To retrieve the contents of the actual error message, use the getBody() method.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("Yahoo Finance","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); var errorMsg = response.getErrorMessage();

children.name: String
children.text: Error message.

children.name: getErrorMessage()
children.text: Gets the error message if there was an error during the REST transaction.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("Yahoo Finance","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); var headerVal = response.getHeader("Content-Type");

children.name: String
children.text: Value of the specified header.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the header that you want the value for, such as Set-Cookie.

children.name: getHeader(String name)
children.text: Gets the value for a specified header.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("Yahoo Finance","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); var headers = response.getHeaders();

children.name: Object
children.text: Object that maps the name of each header to the associated value.

children.name: getHeaders()
children.text: Gets all headers returned in the REST response and the associated values.
children.text2: Note: If a header is present more than once in the response, such as a Set-Cookie header, this function returns only the last of the duplicate headers. To return all headers including duplicates, use the getAllHeaders() function.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("Yahoo Finance","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); var queryString = response.getQueryString();

children.name: String
children.text: Fully-resolved query.

children.name: getQueryString()
children.text: Gets the fully-resolved query sent to the REST endpoint..
children.text2: This query contains the endpoint URL as well as any values assigned to variables in the REST message. Use this method only with responses to direct requests. This method is not supported for requests sent asynchronously, or requests sent using a MID server.

children.name: String
children.text: Sys_id of the new attachment record.

children.name: getResponseAttachmentSysid()
children.text:
Gets the sys_id value of the attachment created from the response body
    content.
children.text2: If the RESTMessageV2 object associated with this response called the saveResponseBodyAsAttachment(...) function, use getResponseAttachmentSysid() to get the sys_id of the created attachment record. Use this function when you want to perform additional operations with the new attachment record.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("Yahoo Finance","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); var statusCode = response.getStatusCode();

children.name: Number
children.text:
Numeric status code returned by the REST provider, such as 200 for a successful
                response.

children.name: getStatusCode()
children.text: Gets the numeric HTTP status code returned by the REST provider.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("Yahoo Finance","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); var error = response.haveError();

children.name: boolean
children.text: Returns true if there was an error, false if there was no error.

children.name: haveError()
children.text: Indicates if there was an error during the REST transaction.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2("Yahoo Finance","get"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.executeAsync(); response.waitForResponse(60);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: timeoutSecs
children.text: Number
children.text2: The amount of time, in seconds, to wait for this response.

children.name: waitForResponse(Number timeoutSecs)
children.text:
Set the amount of time the instance waits for a response from the web service
    provider.
children.text2: This method overrides the property glide.rest.outbound.ecc_response.timeout for this REST response.

name: RESTResponseV2 - Scoped, Global
text:
The RESTResponseV2 API allows you to use the data returned by an outbound REST message
  in JavaScript code.
text2:
A RESTResponseV2 object is returned by the RESTMessageV2 methods execute() and executeAsync().

You can use this API in scoped applications, or within the global scope.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2();

children.name: SOAPMessageV2()
children.text: Instantiates an empty SOAPMessageV2 object.
children.text2: When using an object instantiated this way, you must manually specify a SOAP action and endpoint.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope.

children.name: soapMessage
children.text: String
children.text2: SOAP message record you want to use as the base for this object.

children.name: soapFunction
children.text: String
children.text2:
SOAP function you want to execute. Available SOAP functions depend on the WSDL
                supplied by the web service provider.

children.name: SOAPMessageV2(String soapMessage, String soapFunction)
children.text:
Instantiates a SOAPMessageV2 object from a SOAP message record and a function
    associated with that record.
children.text2: Values such as the endpoint, authentication, or MID Server settings from the SOAP message record apply to this object.

children.name: SOAPResponseV2 - Scoped, Global
children.text: Response returned by the SOAP provider.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); //Might throw exception if http connection timed out or some issue with sending request itself because of encryption/decryption of password.

children.name: execute()
children.text: Sends the SOAP message to the endpoint.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.executeAsync();

children.name: SOAPResponseV2 - Scoped, Global
children.text:
Response returned by the SOAP provider.
Note: Attempting to use the SOAP response object before the response has been processed may result in a timeout error.

children.name: executeAsync()
children.text: Sends the SOAP message to the ECC queue.
children.text2:
SOAP messages in the ECC queue are processed by the SOAPClient business rule.

By default, this business rule does not run asynchronously. To configure this business rule to run asynchronously, set the When value to Async and add current.update() to the end of the Script. The instance does not wait for a response from the web service provider when sending a message through the ECC queue.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var endpoint = sm.getEndpoint();

children.name: String
children.text: URL of the SOAP web service provider.

children.name: getEndpoint()
children.text: Gets the endpoint for the SOAP message.

children.name: String
children.text: SOAP message body.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","StockQuoteSoap.GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var response = sm.execute(); var requestBody = response.getRequestBody();

children.name: getRequestBody()
children.text: Returns the content of the SOAP message body.
children.text2: Note: Before calling the getRequestBody() method, you must call the execute() method to obtain the response object.

children.name: String
children.text: Value of the specified header.

children.name: headerName
children.text: String
children.text2: Request header you want to get the value for.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var header = sm.getRequestHeader("Accept");

children.name: getRequestHeader(String headerName)
children.text: Gets the value for an HTTP header specified by the SOAP client.
children.text2: By default, this method cannot return the value for a header set automatically by the system. To grant this method access to all headers, set the property glide.http.log_debug to true.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var requestHeaders = sm.getRequestHeaders();

children.name: Object
children.text: Object that maps the name of each header to the associated value.

children.name: getRequestHeaders()
children.text:
Gets HTTP headers that were set by the SOAP client and the associated
    values.
children.text2: This method does not return headers set automatically by the system. To configure this method to return all headers, set the property glide.http.log_debug to true.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: userName
children.text: String
children.text2: Username to use when authenticating the SOAP message.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setBasicAuth("username","password");

children.name: userPass
children.text: String
children.text2: Password for the specified user.

children.name: setBasicAuth(String userName, String userPass)
children.text: Sets basic authentication headers for the SOAP message.
children.text2: Setting basic authentication headers using this method overrides basic authentication values defined in the SOAP message record.

children.name: correlator
children.text: String
children.text2: Unique identifier

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setEccCorrelator("unique_id");

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setEccCorrelator(String correlator)
children.text:
Associates outbound requests and the resulting response record in the ECC
    queue.
children.text2: This method only applies to SOAP messages sent through a MID Server. The correlator provided populates the Agent correlator field on the ECC queue record for the response. Provide a unique correlator for each outbound request to associate the correct results in the ECC queue with the request when designing asynchronous automation through a MID Server.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setEccParameter("source","http://very.long.endpoint");

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the ECC parameter.

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2: Value to assign to the specified ECC parameter.

children.name: setEccParameter(String name, String value)
children.text: Overrides a value from the database by writing to the SOAP message payload.
children.text2:
This method only applies to SOAP messages sent through a MID Server. Use this method when a value from the SOAP message in the database is invalid, such as when the endpoint URL is longer than the maximum SOAP endpoint field length.

These are valid values for the name parameter.

  • source: The endpoint URL.
  • name: The SOAP message function to run.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2(); sm.setEndpoint("http://web.service.endpoint");

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: endpoint
children.text: String
children.text2: URL of the SOAP web service provider you want to interface with.

children.name: setEndpoint(String endpoint)
children.text: Sets the endpoint for the SOAP message.
children.text2: By default, the SOAP message uses the endpoint specified in the SOAP message record. Use this method to override the default. You must call this method when using the SOAPMessageV2() constructor with no parameters.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setHttpTimeout(6000);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: timeoutMs
children.text: Number
children.text2:
Amount of time to wait for a response from the web service provider, in
                milliseconds.

children.name: setHttpTimeout(Number timeoutMs)
children.text:
Sets the amount of time the SOAP message waits for a response from the web service
    provider before the request times out.

children.name: level
children.text: String
children.text2: The log level. Valid values are basic, elevated, and all.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setLogLevel(String level)
children.text: Sets the log level for this message and the corresponding response.
children.text2: Setting a log level using the SOAPMessageV2 API overrides the log level configured on the SOAP message record. This log level may not apply if the endpoint domain is excluded, or if the property glide.outbound_http_log.override is true. To view outbound web service logs, navigate to System Logs > Outbound HTTP Requests.

children.name: midServerName
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the MID Server you want to send the SOAP message through. Your instance must have an active MID Server with the specified name.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setMIDServer(String midServerName)
children.text: Configures the SOAP message to be sent through a MID Server.
children.text2: By default, the SOAP message uses the MID Server specified in the SOAP message function record. Use this method to override the default.

children.name: profileName
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the protocol profile to use for mutual authentication.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setMutualAuth("auth_profile_name");

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setMutualAuth(String profileName)
children.text: Sets the mutual authentication protocol profile for the SOAP message.
children.text2: Setting a protocol profile using this method overrides the protocol profile selected for the SOAP message record.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. var body = "<SOAP message body>"; sm.setRequestBody(body);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: requestBody
children.text: String
children.text2: Body of the SOAP message.

children.name: setRequestBody(String requestBody)
children.text: Sets the body content to send to the web service provider.
children.text2: When you set the body content using this method, variables in the body are not substituted for parameters from the SOAP message function record. You must explicitly define all values within the SOAP message body.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: headerName
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the header.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setRequestHeader("Accept","Application/json");

children.name: headerValue
children.text: String
children.text2: Value to assign to the specified header.

children.name: setRequestHeader(String headerName, String headerValue)
children.text: Sets an HTTP header in the SOAP message to the specified value.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2(); sm.setSOAPAction("GetQuote"); //construct SOAP message by specifying endpoint and auth sm.execute();

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: soapAction
children.text: String
children.text2: SOAP action this SOAP message performs.

children.name: setSOAPAction(String soapAction)
children.text: Defines the SOAP action this SOAP message performs.
children.text2: The WSDL for your web service provider lists SOAP actions you can perform. You must call this method when using the SOAPMessageV2() constructor with no parameters.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the SOAP message variable.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setStringParameter("symbol","NOW");

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2: Value to assign to the specified variable.

children.name: setStringParameter(String name, String value)
children.text:
Sets a variable with the specified name from the SOAP message record to the specified
    value.
children.text2: XML reserved characters in the value are converted to the equivalent escaped characters.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the SOAP message variable.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setStringParameterNoEscape("symbol","NOW");

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2: Value to assign to the specified variable.

children.name: setStringParameterNoEscape(String name, String value)
children.text:
Sets a variable with the specified name from the SOAP message record to the specified
    value.
children.text2: This method is equivalent to setStringParameter but does not escape XML reserved characters.

children.name: Example
children.text: var sm = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2("StockQuote","GetQuote"); //Might throw exception if message doesn't exist or not visible due to scope. sm.setWSSecurity("70d65e074f3812001f6eac118110c71a","Quote keys","UXr82cqX75Z7MaSa+EyjGA==","ba969a074f3812001f6eac118110c76d");

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: keystoreId
children.text: String
children.text2: Sys_id of the Java or PKCS12 key store to use.

children.name: keystoreAlias
children.text: String
children.text2: Alias that identifies the public and private keys.

children.name: keystorePassword
children.text: String
children.text2: Password assigned to the key store record.

children.name: certificateId
children.text: String
children.text2: Sys_id of the trusted server certificate.

children.name: setWSSecurity(String keystoreId, String keystoreAlias, String keystorePassword, String certificateId)
children.text: Sets web service security values for the SOAP message.
children.text2: Setting security values using this method overwrites web service security values defined for the SOAP message record.

name: SOAPMessageV2 - Scoped, Global
text: The SOAPMessageV2 API allows you to send an outbound SOAP message using JavaScript.
text2:
Use the SOAPResponseV2 API to manage the response returned by the SOAP provider.

You can use this API in scoped applications, or within the global scope.

See also:
  • Direct SOAPMessageV2 example
  • Recordless SOAPMessageV2 example
  • Asynchronous SOAPMessageV2 example
  • SOAPMessageV2 MID server example

children.name: Example
children.text: var r = new sn_ws.SOAPMessageV2('<A SOAP message>', 'get'); var response = r.execute(); var headers = response.getAllHeaders(); for(var i in headers){ gs.info(headers[i].name + ': ' + headers[i].value); }

children.name: List<GlideHTTPHeader>
children.text:
List of headers contained in the response. Each header is represented as a
                GlideHTTPHeader object which contains the header <var class="keyword varname">name</var> and
                  <var class="keyword varname">value</var>.

children.name: getAllHeaders()
children.text:
Returns all headers contained in the response, including any duplicate
    headers.

children.name: Example
children.text: var body = response.getBody();

children.name: String
children.text: SOAP response body.

children.name: getBody()
children.text: Gets the content of the SOAP response body.

children.name: Output
children.text:
cookie: JSESSIONID=4135AA97A5D12DA22EF614AA2B0CAFD8.node20; Path=/; Secure; HttpOnly
cookie: SABASESSIONID=370152970.36895.0000; path=/

children.name: Example
children.text: var cookies = response.getCookies(); for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; i++) { gs.info('cookie: ' + cookies.get(i)); }
children.text2: Display individual cookies from the response.

children.name: Object
children.text:
Array of strings representing cookies. Iterate through the array to perform
                operations on each cookie.

children.name: getCookies()
children.text: Returns all cookies included in the response.

children.name: Example
children.text: var errorCode = response.getErrorCode();

children.name: Number
children.text: Numeric error code, such as 1 for a socket timeout.

children.name: getErrorCode()
children.text:
Gets the numeric error code if there was an error during the SOAP
    transaction.
children.text2: This error code is specific to the Now Platform, it is not an HTTP error code. Provide this error code if you require assistance from Customer Service and Support.

children.name: Example
children.text: var errorMsg = response.getErrorMessage();

children.name: String
children.text: Error message

children.name: getErrorMessage()
children.text: Gets the error message if there was an error during the SOAP transaction.

children.name: Example
children.text: var headerVal = response.getHeader("Accept");

children.name: String
children.text: Value of the specified header.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the header that you want the value for, such as Set-Cookie.

children.name: getHeader(String name)
children.text: Gets the value for a specified HTTP header.

children.name: Example
children.text: var headers = response.getHeaders();

children.name: Object
children.text: Object that maps the name of each header to the associated value.

children.name: getHeaders()
children.text:
Gets all HTTP headers returned in the SOAP response and the associated
    values.
children.text2: Note: If a header is present more than once in the response, such as a Set-Cookie header, this function returns only the last of the duplicate headers. To return all headers including duplicates, use the getAllHeaders() function.

children.name: Example
children.text: var statusCode = response.getStatusCode();

children.name: Number
children.text:
Numeric status code returned by the SOAP provider, such as 200 for a successful
                response.

children.name: getStatusCode()
children.text: Gets the numeric HTTP status code returned by the SOAP provider.

children.name: Example
children.text: var error = response.haveError();

children.name: boolean
children.text: Returns true if there was an error, false if there was no error.

children.name: haveError()
children.text: Indicates if there was an error during the SOAP transaction.

children.name: Example
children.text: response.waitForResponse(60);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: timeoutSecs
children.text: Number
children.text2: Amount of time, in seconds, to wait for this response.

children.name: waitForResponse(Number timeoutSecs)
children.text:
Sets the amount of time the instance waits for a response from the web service
    provider.
children.text2: This method overrides the property glide.soap.outbound.ecc_response.timeout for this SOAP response.

name: SOAPResponseV2 - Scoped, Global
text: The SOAPResponseV2 API allows you to use the data returned by an outbound SOAP message in JavaScript code.
text2:
A SOAPResponseV2 object is returned by the SOAPMessageV2 methods execute() and executeAsync().

You can use this API in scoped applications, or within the global scope.

See also:
  • Direct SOAPMessageV2 example
  • Recordless SOAPMessageV2 example
  • Asynchronous SOAPMessageV2 example
  • SOAPMessageV2 MID server example
